sec.p: It is within this context that, given these intriguing implications, the Conservative Democrats’ pragmatist IR strategy could not be aligned solely with any one of those three motives in systemic terms in spite of its bias towards neoliberalism. What makes the JDP’s pragmatism hard and unique is its complex and intractable nature arising out of the use of these three opposite motives, with changing emphasis. It is hard because the JDP has to pragmatically fine-tune the relative weight of those three motives under the constraint of co-managing a lot of ‘opposing’ factors such as high unemployment and trade union rights, capturing the support of both employers and labour, the democratization reforms in terms of IR required by the EU acquis and fiscal discipline as another parameter conditioned by the Maastricht criteria, etc. (These factors are not necessarily opposite, but the JDP’s policy adaptations in IR indicate that the party perceives them as such.) In this regard, unlike the incumbent governments during the development and dissolution periods of Turkish IR, the JDP has had to initiate or at least to articulate some reforms even though these reforms have not had systemic impact. By and large, the governments sustained the balance of power established by the military governments at the beginning of these periods. Thus, they were inclined either to commit to the status quo by refraining from making or even articulating changes that would undermine the established power relations in IR, or to adopt simple pragmatic actions, such as wage and salary increases before general elections. In reality, the JDP’s reforms have had little, if any, actual impact. What differentiates the JDP from the previous governments is that it has pragmatically reconfigured the Turkish system of IR in discourse and practice without any real involvement of the Turkish military. Furthermore, it managed this reconfiguration in such a manner that it could win the support of labour and employers and has even increased its support for the upcoming elections. The JDP constructed a new vision by creating a social democratic IR discourse that allowed it to perpetuate its central position in Turkish politics and to fulfil the requirements of this discourse under the shadow of its neoliberal politico-economic agenda. It is this delicate balance between discourse and practice that makes the JDP’s hard pragmatism a double-edged IR strategy that at once suppresses and supports organized labour.

In this sense, the JDP could not sustain a directly suppressive IR strategy, as the Motherland Party did between 1983 and 1991. The JDP has been in power during a period in which the dominant ideology is a neoliberalism that envisages the complete elimination of organized labour. This ‘strong’ contextual factor provides the party with an opportunity to dismantle organized labour. The JDP has not hesitated to use the neoliberal status quo in Turkish IR as leverage to implement its hard pragmatism. However, were the JDP to adopt a purely neoliberal strategy, it could not obtain the support of the working class. Furthermore, the JDP cannot take the risk of a massive conflict with the working class in other respects, especially when this risk is combined with existing political tensions. In addition to undermining the JDP’s popular image, this risk would change this so-called ‘political tension’ into a regime-based clash. Another factor is the EU membership process, which was the prime initiator of democratization reforms within IR during the reorganization crisis between 2002 and 2010. Even if the EU factor does not become influential in this regard (which appears to be the case with respect to the operation of the ESC and JCC because the IR stipulations within the EU acquis process are non-binding), it still rules out the implementation of anti-democratic regulations. This point is significant for the JDP’s general democratic image in terms of the state–civil society relationship, even if IR is perceived to be a marginal element of the EU accession reforms.

Along with the unfeasibility of maintaining the previous neoliberal status quo as it was, it is also not propitious for the Conservative Democrats to implement their social democratic discourse abruptly, as the RPP did while regulating the TUA and CBSLA of 1963. In such a case, as discussed above, the JDP is likely to have to set fiscal discipline aside because organized labour, especially the civil servants, would be able to challenge the government’s politico-economic strategies. This conflict would put economic stability, the prime determinant of the JDP’s electoral success, at risk (see Çarkoğlu, 2008), and it would become inconceivable for the JDP to sustain a cross-class alliance. It should also be noted, however, that the JDP cannot calmly overlook its social democratic promises because the Turkish working class has tactical competence sufficient to eliminate such simple pragmatism. The collapse of the political establishment in the general elections of November 2002 was a landmark in this regard; none of the three political parties in the DLP-led coalition government could enter the Turkish parliament because none could meet the 10 percent national threshold. For example, thanks to its social democratic promises, notably its support of the working class, the DLP took 22.9 percent of the total votes in the 1999 general election, but this rate fell to 1.2 percent in the 2002 general elections. It argues safe to say that the aforementioned neoliberal IR policy of the DLP-led government, in opposition to Ecevit’s social democratic discourse, played an important role in the DLP’s loss of 21.7 percent of the vote. As a political party that rose up out of these ruins, the JDP could not take the risk of cutting wages and salaries or neglecting its social democratic promises, as did its predecessor.

Due to the politico-economic risk, the JDP could neither formulate nor implement a pure Islamist IR strategy either. An IR strategy should be part of a general politico-economic project, such as the Just Order; these projects are likely to stir up regime-based conflict between the JDP and the labour organizations, as was the case between the Welfare Party and the leading trade union organizations. The emergence of Conservative Democracy, in essence, rests on the elimination of this risk. Even without this risk, the party would not sustain the IR premises of the Just Order because it could not, in this case, put into effect its hard pragmatism in IR. In this respect, the Just Order’s ‘social justice first’ manifesto (see Erbakan, 1991) would call for the relaxation of austerity corporatism to provide a decent work environment, and its anti-capitalist rhetoric would rule out any sustainable relationship with TUSIAD. (To operationalize its hard pragmatism in IR, the JDP chooses to maintain economic and political stability over providing a decent work environment. Even if the party does not aspire to establish an employer-friendly IR structure, its austere corporatism singles out economic stability as the prime determinant of electoral success. Furthermore, it emphasizes providing a favourable investment environment for employers more than it emphasizes providing a decent working environment for employees.) The maintenance of the Just Order’s IR strategy is also not feasible for the party because it cannot sustain its popularity by camouflaging its neoliberal policies in a social democratic IR discourse and in the aforementioned diplomatic manoeuvres.

What should be done if the party cannot adopt a purely neoliberal, social democratic or Islamist IR policy in discourse and practice? The solution is hard pragmatism, as described in this article. It should also be noted that the other factor reinforcing the JDP’s pragmatism is that the labour organizations and opposition parties are unable to develop effective counter-strategies. Trade unions blame the JDP for adopting such a political stance (hard pragmatism), which unsurprisingly is designed to maintain the party’s hold on power, rather than to have created a pro-union environment by providing the trade unions with truly democratic rights without expecting them to engage in any political exchange. The reason for this expectation is that throughout the evolution of Turkish IR, the state has unilaterally set the rules and power relationships. The trade unions and civil servants do not criticize themselves for their failure to compel the JDP to democratize IR. In terms of the interplay between organized labour and the incumbent government, IR is a game of political exchange in which labour must in turn create its own input to force the government to take its demands seriously. The only available means for the unions is to encourage its members to vote or not to vote for the government. However, in Turkish politics, both civil servant and trade unions are incapable of such an action. For example, as mentioned earlier, the JDP enjoys support in working-class towns where massive privatizations were implemented (see Figure 6). As Yıldırım (2006) argued, the trade unions have failed to encourage their members not to vote for the JDP in these areas.4

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: As discussed in the first part of this article, Turkish IR, since its institutionalization in the late 1940s, has been conducted by incumbent civil or military governments according to the requirements of their pragmatist or authoritarian politico-economic strategies. The Conservative Democrats have chosen to maintain this tradition by creating a ‘hard pragmatism’, which aims to establish an IR structure that will not restrain but feed their austere economic policy and catch-all politics. What makes the JDP’s pragmatism ‘hard’ is that it has been put into effect by means of an intriguing IR discourse and practice consisting of Islamist, neoliberal and social democrat motives. The JDP’s multivariate approach, which manages the shifting weights of these three motives, has enabled them to maintain the support of the Turkish working class. Although, under this hard pragmatist perspective, the JDP has implemented some noteworthy changes in favour of organized labour, these changes have not had a systemic impact on the overall functioning of Turkish IR. Rather, as Table 1 shows, the party used the controlling policy tools of Turkish IR under the protective umbrella of its populist discourse. As a result, the panorama is a pending reorganizational crisis arising out of the confrontation between the JDP’s populist discourse, non-systemic changes and entrenched systemic peculiarities of Turkish IR. It is possible to suggest that the party has produced this crisis intentionally (and, admittedly, managed it effectively in terms of its political career) by following up its so-called hard pragmatism with subsequent diplomatic manoeuvres. Organized labour’s failure to create a political exchange and to develop influential strategies against these manoeuvres has facilitated the manipulative power of the JDP. In this respect, the passivity of the trade and civil service unions and their ineffective participation in public sector collective meetings, the ESC and the JCC have served to leave the JDP’s hard pragmatism unchallenged. This power imbalance can be seen, for example, in rapidly decreasing trade union membership rates and in the continuing ban on collective bargaining and right to strike for civil service unions. Furthermore, organized labour has made no promising response to these issues. Thus, there is no evidence to refute the conclusion that Conservative Democracy, as a hard pragmatic strategy of IR, will continue to exist should the JDP remain in power after the general elections in June 2011. The main opposition party’s failure to develop a genuine alternative strengthens this possibility in terms of IR.

During the Tekel workers’ protests for improvements in their working conditions, the chairman of the Tek Gıda-Is trade union declared, ‘If it becomes a necessity, we will overthrow the government.’ Admittedly, such a ‘socialist’ discourse is no less pragmatic than Tayyip Erdoğan’s social democratic discourse because the trade unions are unable to convince even their own members not to vote for the JDP. In contrast, the JDP has been able to convert its pragmatism into votes among the working class. Tayyip Erdoğan’s response to this pragmatic response confirms this phenomenon. He said, ‘They think that this country consists solely of themselves. The JDP came to power by cultivating 15 million votes. How many members do you have? How will you overthrow the JDP government, which has 15 million members and is so close to its workers and civil servants?’ (Daily Milliyet, 2010). Moreover, the fact that there is no genuine alternative party for the workers strengthens the JDP’s position. The IR career of the main opposition party, the RPP, has been highly ambiguous. The RPP has no decisive social democratic discourse like Tayyip Erdoğan’s and certainly does not have a full-fledged programme to democratize IR. The new chairman of the RPP could not succeed in cultivating such a programme under an authoritative politico-economic project; rather, in a response to the question of where he would find the resources to finance higher social expenditure, he said, ‘My name is Kemal. I will find the resources’ (Daily Milliyet, 2011). This outlook is a kind of simplistic pragmatism because he is not aware of the transformation of social democracy in Europe stemming from the search for resources for so-called social expenditure over the past three decades. This approach is simply not convincing for the Turkish working class because of their aforementioned experiences during era of the DLP-led coalition government. They are aware that, in the Turkish context, simplistic pragmatist policy adaptations will end in economic catastrophes that will considerably diminish their earnings, as occurred in 2001 under the DLP-led coalition. And what persuades them to vote for the JDP is their double shuffle in making a ‘hard choice’ between the simplistic and hard versions of pragmatism in IR; it seems that they will face a similar choice in the upcoming general elections in June 2011.
